string-array.name: not_your_fault_messages
string-array.item: Whatever happened, was not your fault. No one has the right to sexually violet you. The blame for a rape lies solely with the rapist. The truth is that what a person wears, what a person says, or how a person acts is never a justification for sexual violence.
Most people are raped by people they know. You do not have to protect the perpetrator. Make protecting yourself your priority. Do not worry about protecting the person who raped you.
If you want to report the crime to the police, do so. Reporting sexual violence may help protect others from that person — and may help you feel a little less like you were a victim.

string-array.name: seek_medical_care_messages
string-array.item: 40% of rape survivors develop sexually transmitted diseases as a result of sexual assault.

You should get medical attention right away without changing your clothes, showering, douching, or washing. It can be hard not to clean up, of course — it is a natural human instinct to wash away all traces of a sexual assault. But being examined right away is the best way to ensure you get proper medical treatment.

Immediate medical attention helps when people decide to report the crime, providing evidence needed to prosecute the rapist if a criminal case is pursued. If you have been raped and think you do not want to report it, you could change your mind later and having the results of a medical exam can help you do this.

Even if you do not get examined right away, it does not mean you cannot get a checkup later. It is always best to see a doctor immediately after a rape, of course. But a person can still go to a doctor or local clinic to get checked out for STDs, pregnancy, or injuries any time after being raped. In some cases, doctors can even gather evidence several days after a rape has occurred.
All doctors and nurses will deal with your medical needs confidentially, and they will not inform anyone without your consent

string-array.name: signs_of_sgbv
string-array.item: Beware of torn, stained, or bloody underclothing as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of pain or itching in genital area as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of difficulty walking or sitting as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of bruises or bleeding in genital areas as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of frequent urinary or yeast infections as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of sexually transmitted diseases as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Chronic depression as a behavioral symptom is far more common than physical ones
Pain or itching in genital area is a sign of sexual violence
The survivor might have difficulty walking or sitting
The Bruises or bleeding in genital areas is a sign of sexual violence
Beware of frequent urinary or yeast infections
Beware of Sexually transmitted diseases after sexual violence

resources.string: Thank you for submitting the Incident. The incident was successfully delivered to SafePal. \nSafePal will in a short while provide you with a person to assist you.
We have located the nearest ... (CSO) to you.\nThe people at this CSO have already gotten information about this incident and they will be contacting you soon.\nBelow are the details of this CSO.
Would you like to contact you?
